li.p: Define combinations of functions and apply and interpret these in appropriate situations.

section.title: Gist of Combinations of Functions
section.p: A combination of functionsfunctioncombination is the result of performing an arithmetic operation on the outputs of two or more functions.

li.p: The ouputs of two functions are added together.
The ouputs of two functions are divided.
The output of one function is used as an exponent on the output of the other function.

section.p: Note that this is different from the composition of functions from chapter, where the output of one function was used as the input of another function.
Typical combinations in this course are adding, subtracting, multiplying or dividing functions, though any operation on two or more numbers would correspond to a function combination.

section.p: An example of function combinations involves Profit, Revenue and Cost.

example.p: It costs money to manufacture a product, and you can make money by selling it. The profit is the difference between how much money you collect from selling the product (called the revenue), and how much it costs you to manufacture it.

Let C(u) be the cost, in thousands of dollars, of manufacturing u tons of a product. Let R(u) be the revenue, in thousands of dollars, collected through selling u tons of the product. Finally, P(u) is the profit, in thousands of dollars, from making and selling u tons of the product.
Using function notation, we would write:P(u) = R(u) - C(u)

statement.p: In business, we use the equation P(u) = R(u) - C(u) where P(u) is the profit you make from selling u tons of some product, after you pay expenses. The function R(u) represents the revenue from selling the product, and C(u) represents the costs you must pay to manufacture the product.

Thus, as the number of items increases, the cost of each one will decrease.
